awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Permian and Triassic Icehouse to Greenhouse Paleoenvironments and Paleobotany in the Shackleton Glacier Area, Antarctica
awd_abstract_narration:
The focus of this collaborative project is to collect fossil plants, wood, and sedimentary and chemical information from rocks in the Shackleton Glacier (SHK) area of Antarctica. This information will be used to reconstruct plant life and environments during the Permian and Triassic (~295-205 million years ago) in Antarctica. This time interval is important to study as Antarctica experienced a large glaciation in the Permian followed by deglaciation and recovery of plant and animal life, only to be subjected to the largest extinction in Earth history at the end of the Permian. After the extinction events, the climate in Antarctica continued to warm extensively and there were forests growing close to the paleo-South Pole. These ancient environments provide a natural laboratory in which to study the effects of climate change on plant life. The results of this project will advance the field in the areas of changing sedimentary patterns during global cooling and warming, as well as plant evolution during times following glaciation and during global warmth. 

This project will study the extent of the Gondwana glaciation in the SHK area, the invasion and subsequent flourishing of life following glacial retreat, and the eventual recovery of plant life after Late Permian extinction events. Only in Antarctica does a complete polar-to-near-polar succession occur across this climatic and biologic transition. The SHK area is an important one as it is one of the few regions in the world where the Permian-Triassic boundary (PTB) is exposed within terrestrial rocks. The field and lab work for this project is organized around three hypotheses that address fundamental issues in Earth history, including changes in the extent and diversity of flora during the Permian build up to the Late Paleozoic Ice Age, the possible diachronous nature of the PTB, and that poor fossil preservation during the Early Triassic has given a false impression that Antarctica was devoid of plants during this time.  The hypotheses will be tested by integrating various types of paleobotanical approaches with detailed sedimentology, stratigraphy, and geochemistry.  Compression floras and petrified wood will be collected (constrained by stratigraphy) both quantitatively and qualitatively in order to obtain biodiversity and abundance data, and as a data source for paleoecological analysis. Standard sedimentologic and stratigraphic analyses will be performed, as well as paleosol analyses, including mineralogic and major- and trace-element geochemistry. Collections will also be made for U-Pb zircon geochronology to better constrain geologic and biotic events through time. Results of the project will be incorporated into educational and outreach activities that are designed to include women and under-represented groups in the excitement of Antarctic earth sciences and paleontology, including workshops in Kansas and Wisconsin, as well as links to science classes during fieldwork.

This collaborative project between the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee (UWM) and the University of Kansas (KU) investigated paleoclimate, landscape evolution, and paleo-floristic changes that occurred in Antarctica (Shackleton Glacier area) and across the southern supercontinent, Gondwana, during the late Paleozoic Ice Age (LPIA), the Permian Icehouse to Greenhouse transition, the End-Permian Mass Extinction, and the ensuing Triassic recovery. Examined strata included: Permian (Pagoda, Mackellar, Fairchild, and Buckley fms) and Triassic (Fremouw Fm) units. Our group conducted two field seasons in the Shackleton Glacier area of Antarctica (2016-17 and 2017-18) utilizing helicopters and fixed wing aircraft working out of the Shackleton Glacier Camp to access sites at Collinson Ridge, Kitching Ridge, Alfie?s Elbow, Mt. Butters (2 sites), Reed Spur, Mt. Munson, Graphite Peak, Schroeder Hill, McIntyre Promontory, Mt. Rosenwald, and Mt. Weaver. UK scientists focused on Permian -Triassic fossil plants with their results summarized in a separate project report (Project # 1443546). For UWM, Isbell and Ph.D. student, Libby Ives, concentrated on understanding the climatic and landscape evolution during the LPIA and its transition into the Late Permian and Early Triassic greenhouse. Gulbranson focused on the paleoecology and geochemistry of paleosols and fossil tree-ring analysis. All project members focused on locating the Buckley Fremouw Fm contact and the probable Permian-Triassic boundary.  This study is part of a long-term project attempting to synthesize climate change across Gondwana. Therefore, results from the Shackleton Glacier area were synthesized to provide a more complete picture for the Carboniferous-Triassic of Antarctica and Gondwana.  

Traditional LPIA studies identify glaciation as a protracted event with waxing and waning of a single, massive, ice sheet centered over the present central Transantarctic Mountains (Permian South Pole) and extending outward over Gondwana. However, our results indicate that at least two ice sheets, one in Marie Byrd Land and the other on the East Antarctic Craton, drained ice into an elongate, trough-like Transantarctic Basin. Parts of the basin were ice free throughout the LPIA. This supports an emerging view that the LPIA consisted of multiple smaller ice sheets that fluctuated asynchronously across Gondwana, and that Antarctica was not the hypothetical center of a massive ice sheet. In conjunction with our studies elsewhere, we recognize a stepwise deglaciation occurred across Gondwana beginning in the Early Pennsylvanian in western South America, then shifting across eastern South America, Southern Africa, and Antarctica in the latest Pennsylvanian and Early Permian before ending near the Middle-Late Permian boundary in eastern Australia. The transition from icehouse to greenhouse was driven my both regional (e.g., changing tectonic conditions, changing moisture sources) and global (e.g., insolation, continental drift over the South Pole, changing atmospheric CO2 concentrations) controls.

Deposition of the coal-bearing, Middle and Late Permian Buckley FM occurred within an under-filled, elongate, trough-shaped, foreland basin in/on braided rivers, crevasse splays, and floodplains characterized by extensive high water-table environments (wetlands, mires, lakes). Shifting drainage patterns, water tables, and basin geometry resulted from asymmetric flexural subsidence/uplift  (tectonic and sediment loading) within the basin. Strata across the Buckley-Fremouw contact display changing sandstone stacking patterns, a change in color, the loss of preserved organic matter, a loss of coals, and the loss of a preserved floral record. The formational contact is often thought of as the P-T boundary and these changes are often hypothesized as resulting from vegetation loss due to the P-T extinction event. However, these changes, and the Buckley-Fremouw contact, are diachronous across the basin, and therefore, are likely due to shifting basinal conditions as well as global change. Triassic strata of the Fremouw Fm show evidence of deposition in/on braided streams and well-drained floodplains, and were deposited in an over-filled, foreland basin sloping away from the presumed orogenic belt. Lower water tables are expected in such basinal conditions.  Paleoclimate simulations indicate that the Permian polar environment was characterized by a surplus of water during the austral summer relative to the Triassic, consistent with paleosol morphology, suggesting that paleoclimate variations and changing basinal geometries exerted a prominent control on vegetation-river dynamics. No evidence of freezing conditions was identified within post LPIA Permian and Triassic strata.

Five Permian fossil forests were identified. Three distinct ecologic niches were identified for the paleo-forests at Collinson Ridge and represent the single highest diversity assemblage of ecologic niches so far recognized in Antarctica.  Dendrochronology cross-matching of woody debris relative to in situ stumps indicates that woody debris deposition in river channels was contemporaneous with the development of vegetated macroforms in Permian in-channel deposits. Whereas, Triassic woody debris occur without evidence of vegetated macroforms, yet the volume and areal distribution of Triassic woody debris is greater than that measured in the Permian. Fossil soil geochemistry and climate simulations suggest that the plant response to climate change resulted in enhanced stress during the late Permian, which likely caused the demise of the Glossopteris flora in Antarctica.
